qas.question: Which lobes of the lungs are more often affected by TB?
What symptom will result if TB infection causes a Rasmussen's aneurysm?
What percentage of tuberculosis infections don't ever manifest in symptoms of the disease?
If TB becomes chronic, what lasting effect might it have on the lung's upper lobes?
Approximately what percentage of active TB cases affect the lungs?
What percentage of cases include chest pain?
What is it called when people have symptoms?
What percentage of cases erode into the pulmonary artery?
What kind of aneurysm does chest pain in TB patients sometimes result in?
What are lower lobes in the lungs often more affected by?

context: If a tuberculosis infection does become active, it most commonly involves the lungs (in about <a4_0><b5_0>90%<b5_0/><a4_0/> of cases). Symptoms may include chest pain and a prolonged cough producing sputum. About <a2_0><b7_0>25%<b7_0/><a2_0/> of people may not have any symptoms (i.e. they remain "<b6_0>asymptomatic<b6_0/>"). Occasionally, people may cough up blood in small amounts, and in very rare cases, the infection may erode into the pulmonary artery or a <b8_0>Rasmussen's<b8_0/> aneurysm, resulting in <a1_0>massive bleeding<a1_0/>. Tuberculosis may become a chronic illness and cause extensive <a3_0>scarring<a3_0/> in the upper lobes of the lungs. The <a0_0>upper lung lobes<a0_0/> are more frequently affected by <b9_0>tuberculosis<b9_0/> than the lower ones. The reason for this difference is not clear. It may be due either to better air flow, or to poor lymph drainage within the upper lungs.
